name: Photography Darkroom

mappings.label: Camera Body
mappings.description: A camera body is the foundation tool that determines how images are captured — analogous to how a checkpoint model determines the visual style and capabilities of generated images. The camera body holds the sensor (model weights) that interprets light (latent space). Strength: intuitive selection of a physical tool. Weakness: checkpoint loading is passive selection, while a camera body implies active shooting.

facadeControls.label: Camera Model
facadeControls.rationale: Selecting a camera model (Canon 5D, Sony A7, etc.) maps directly to checkpoint selection. Users recognize 'pick a camera' immediately.

mappings.assetPrompt: Professional camera body viewed from a three-quarter angle, resting on a dark wooden workbench in warm amber safelight, metallic finish catching light, mounted on a tripod foot, clean illustration style, 256x256

animationHints.idle: Camera body sits still with a faint lens glint
animationHints.active: Subtle aperture blade animation, indicator LED pulses softly

mappings.label: Positive Light Setup
mappings.description: In photography, lighting is what sculpts the subject. Positive prompts are the directional, defining light that shapes the image. This maps text-to-embedding by treating the prompt as a lighting directive. Strength: text input remains explicitly textual (users write the prompt as a description). Weakness: light is unidirectional and simple; prompts are complex and layered.

facadeControls.label: Positive Light Description
facadeControls.rationale: Users type a natural language description of what lighting/composition they want. The text field remains fully visible — no abstraction of the prompt itself.

mappings.assetPrompt: Studio lighting setup with two large softboxes and key light positioned at 45 degrees, warm color temperature, diffusion panels visible, hanging from overhead rigs in a darkroom, amber gels, clean illustration style, 256x256

animationHints.idle: Soft glow pulses gently from the light banks
animationHints.active: Lights brighten and flicker as if adjusting during a shoot

mappings.label: Negative Light Setup
mappings.description: Negative prompts define what to exclude — analogous to fill light, flags, or black cards that block unwanted light and prevent certain reflections. Strength: the negation concept maps to light control (preventing vs. creating). Weakness: negative prompts are complex filters, while negative light is simpler than positive.

facadeControls.label: Negative Light Description
facadeControls.rationale: Users type what to avoid/remove, just as a photographer uses black flags to block stray light. Text remains explicit.

mappings.assetPrompt: Black absorptive flags, barn doors, and negative fill panels blocking light in a darkroom, matte black fabric, mounted on stands, casting shadows, amber safelight backdrop, clean illustration style, 256x256

animationHints.idle: Flags remain still, creating sharp shadows
animationHints.active: Flags shift slightly as adjustments are made

mappings.label: Blank Film Roll
mappings.description: An empty film roll is unexposed, ready to capture light. Latent space is abstract but can be thought of as the 'potential' state before image decoding — like film before it's exposed. The roll's dimensions (width, height) and batch size map to film format and frame count. Strength: physical analogy for 'empty, ready state'. Weakness: latent space is not truly visual; users don't directly interact with film rolls in modern workflows.

facadeControls.label: Frame Width (pixels)
facadeControls.rationale: A film roll's frame width. Standard cinema film has standard widths — slider shows pixel dimensions.

facadeControls.label: Frame Height (pixels)
facadeControls.rationale: Frame height, mapping to aspect ratio. Photography conventions: 16:9, 4:3, 1:1 are common.

facadeControls.label: Frame Count
facadeControls.rationale: How many blank frames on the roll. Multiple exposures = batch generation.

mappings.assetPrompt: A 35mm film roll standing upright on a shelf in a darkroom, fresh and unused, glossy silver canister with blank label, red darkroom lights creating warm highlights on the roll, clean illustration style, 256x256

animationHints.idle: Film roll sits still, faint sheen on the canister
animationHints.active: Roll rotates slightly as if frames are being positioned

mappings.label: Exposure Chamber
mappings.description: The Exposure Chamber is where light (conditioning + latent state) interacts over time to develop an image. Diffusion sampling iteratively refines the latent space — like film slowly accumulating exposed silver halide crystals during a long exposure. Strength: the iterative refinement maps well to cumulative light exposure. Weakness: diffusion sampling is not truly additive light; it's iterative denoising.

facadeControls.label: Exposure Duration (steps)
facadeControls.rationale: More steps = longer exposure time. Each step is a moment of light interaction. Intuitive: photographers understand that longer exposure gathers more detail.

facadeControls.label: Light Intensity (Guidance)
facadeControls.rationale: CFG scale controls how strongly the prompt conditions the diffusion. Higher CFG = stronger adherence to the prompt, like increasing light intensity to ensure the subject is clearly defined.

facadeControls.label: Film Grain (Seed)
facadeControls.rationale: The seed controls randomness, like different film stocks have different grain patterns. Users can lock a seed to get reproducible results, or randomize for variation.

facadeControls.label: Sampling Method
facadeControls.rationale: The sampler algorithm (Euler, DPM++, etc.) is like choosing a film development method — different chemicals and processes yield different tonal curves.

mappings.assetPrompt: A large glass chamber with swirling light patterns inside, mounted on a darkroom bench, containing luminous fog being refined by beams of red and amber safelight, mechanical timer dial on the front, clean illustration style, 256x256

animationHints.idle: Faint glow swirls inside the chamber, ambient mist drifts slowly
animationHints.active: Interior brightens and swirls intensify; light patterns dance more rapidly as steps progress
animationHints.transition: Glow intensifies then settles as exposure completes

mappings.label: Chemical Developer Bath
mappings.description: In traditional darkroom work, the developer bath chemically reveals the latent image on film — exposed silver halide becomes metallic silver. VAE decoding translates latent space back into pixel space, much like developer reveals the hidden image. Strength: the chemical transformation is an excellent analogy for latent→pixel conversion. Weakness: VAE decode is a neural network operation, not chemistry; users don't control it directly.
mappings.assetPrompt: A traditional darkroom development tray filled with amber-colored chemical solution, film hanging above it dripping into the bath, steam rising gently, processing trays arranged in a row, red safelight reflection on the liquid surface, clean illustration style, 256x256

animationHints.idle: Liquid surface ripples gently, wisps of steam rise intermittently
animationHints.active: Liquid bubbles and churns as the film develops; image gradually appears
animationHints.transition: Fade as the film is lifted and the image is revealed

mappings.label: Print Dryer & Archive
mappings.description: The final step: a print dryer in a darkroom that readies the finished photograph for archival storage. This is where the developed image is secured and stored with a name/catalog number. Strength: intuitive final step — you dry, name, and file your work. Weakness: the output is a digital file, not a physical print, but the metaphor captures the essence of 'finalization'.

facadeControls.label: Print Label / Filename
facadeControls.rationale: Users type a name/prefix for their saved images, like writing a label on a print before archiving. Keeps the output explicitly named and organized.

mappings.assetPrompt: A heated print dryer with finished photographic prints emerging from the top slot, metal frame with ventilation grates, warm amber lighting from inside, prints stacked neatly on a shelf below ready for filing, warm darkroom ambience, clean illustration style, 256x256

animationHints.idle: Dryer hums quietly, warm glow pulses from vents
animationHints.active: Prints slowly emerge from the slot; labels appear as they're marked
animationHints.transition: Prints settle into the archive with a satisfied 'click'

threadStyle.metaphor: Photographic workflow threads: model flows like the camera's internal lens path, text prompts flow like light through the optical system, latent space flows like film being exposed, images flow like developed prints moving through the dryer.

waveMetaphor: Tokens flow like light through glass (yellow for prompts), like electrical pulses through camera circuits (brown for models), like film grain accumulating (gray dashed for latent), and like processed prints moving on conveyor rollers (white for final images).
sceneDescription: A professional photography darkroom viewed from above. The workflow progresses left to right: Camera body stands on the left workbench, connected via optical paths to adjustable light setups (positive and negative). In the center, a blank film roll awaits exposure in a luminous chamber where light and latent states interact. On the right, the developed film emerges into a chemical bath, then moves to a heated print dryer. Throughout, amber and red safelights cast warm glows on brass-and-glass equipment. The space feels analog, timeless, and intentional — every tool has a clear purpose in transforming imagination into image.

sceneConfig.backgroundPrompt: A professional photography darkroom viewed from directly above, wide angle perspective showing the complete workflow layout. Left to right: camera body and tripod on a wooden bench, two adjustable light stands with softboxes and black flags framing a central chamber, a glass exposure chamber with swirling amber light, development trays filled with chemical solution in the middle ground, a heated print dryer on the right with prints emerging, and storage shelves with filed prints in the background. Red and amber safelights cast warm glows throughout. Brass pipes, glass panels, and copper wire visible. Warm color palette with deep shadows. Wooden workbenches, stainless steel trays, brass fittings. Digital illustration, clean lines, atmospheric but not photorealistic, 1024x512.
sceneConfig.ambientDescription: Warm amber and red safelights pulse gently throughout the space. Steam rises in thin wisps from the developer bath. The exposure chamber glows with inner luminescence that subtly shifts as processing occurs. Print dryer hums softly with warm ventilation. Occasional metallic clinks as prints are handled. The air feels heavy with chemical scent (implied but not depicted). Liquid surfaces ripple gently.
sceneConfig.layoutHints: Arrange elements left-to-right in a linear workflow: Camera Body (far left) → Positive/Negative Light Setups (left-center, side by side) → Blank Film Roll (center) → Exposure Chamber (center-right) → Developer Bath/Chemical Tray (right-center) → Print Dryer (far right). Thread paths should flow logically through this sequence, with the model threading from Camera to all processing stages.

aiVocabulary: In the Darkroom metaphor, the workflow is narrated as follows: 'Load your camera body (checkpoint model). Set up your positive lighting to define how the subject should appear, and your negative lighting to control what you don't want. Prepare a blank film roll with your desired frame dimensions and batch size. Place the film in the exposure chamber, where it will be illuminated by your lighting setup for a duration you choose (steps), with intensity governed by your guidance settings and grain determined by your seed selection. Once exposure is complete, the film moves to the chemical developer, where the latent image is chemically revealed. Finally, the developed prints are dried and archived under your chosen filename. The result is a series of finished photographs.'

attributeScores.rationale: Photographers immediately understand 'selecting a camera model'. The dropdown presents named options just like Canon/Sony/Nikon choices. The metaphor truthfully represents that checkpoint selection fundamentally determines output characteristics.

mappingScores.rationale: Strong mapping. Camera bodies are physical, recognizable tools that users understand. They accept no traditional inputs but output signal flow to downstream processes — matches the checkpoint role exactly. Minor weakness: checkpoint selection is passive, but camera body implies an active shooting tool.

attributeScores.rationale: Text input remains fully textual — users type descriptions. The label 'Positive Light Description' hints at the analogy without hiding the prompt mechanism. Truthfulness is high: light is indeed positive/directional. Intuitiveness is moderate because 'light description' is slightly abstracted; users must bridge from 'light' back to 'prompt semantics'.

mappingScores.rationale: Good mapping because text input remains explicit. Light as a metaphor for 'what to emphasize' is reasonable but not perfect — prompts are semantic, while light is physical. The conditioning output is invisible (embeddings), which is fine; no loss of clarity here.

attributeScores.rationale: Negation maps reasonably to 'blocking light with flags', but the metaphor is weaker here. Negative prompts are semantic filters (exclude concepts), while blocking light is physical blocking. Users understand flags prevent reflections, but the abstraction distance is greater than for positive prompts.

mappingScores.rationale: Functional but strained. Text input is preserved (good), but the 'negative light' concept is less intuitive than positive light. In photography, negative fill is subtle and technical; most users think of positive light first. The metaphor holds but requires more explanation.

attributeScores.rationale: Film rolls have standard widths. Slider maps directly to pixel width. Users understand 'wider frame = more horizontal space'.
Height slider is clear and truthful. Aspect ratio control is familiar to photographers.
Multiple frames on a roll = batch generation. Clear and intuitive.

mappingScores.rationale: Strong mapping for the tangible parameters (dimensions, count). Latent space itself is not visual, but a 'blank film roll' is a good proxy for 'empty potential state ready for exposure'. Users won't directly manipulate latent space — it's passed through — so the mapping works without overwhelming detail. Minor weakness: latent space is abstract; users might not fully grasp that this element represents a neural-network intermediate state, not actual film.

attributeScores.rationale: Steps = exposure time is intuitive. Photographers understand longer exposures capture more detail. However, diffusion sampling is iterative denoising, not cumulative photon collection, so truthfulness is moderate — the metaphor works but glosses over the actual algorithm.

CFG scale as 'light intensity' requires a cognitive leap. Technically, CFG controls adherence to the prompt, not light intensity. The metaphor is functional but not perfectly truthful. Higher CFG does enforce the prompt more strictly, somewhat like increasing light to 'define' subjects, but the analogy is loose.

Film grain varies with film stock, and seed determines randomness in diffusion sampling. The analogy works: different grain patterns = different random starting points. Truthfulness is moderate because 'grain' affects texture, while 'seed' affects global composition. Still, both impart variation.

Different sampler algorithms are like different development methods or film stocks. The analogy works conceptually, but users unfamiliar with sampling algorithms won't intuitively understand the difference between Euler and DPM++. Truthfulness is good (different algorithms do yield different results), but intuitiveness is limited.

mappingScores.rationale: Moderate-to-good mapping. The core concept (exposure chamber iteratively refining an image) is solid, and most controls map reasonably. However, CFG scale and sampler selection are somewhat forced metaphorically. The element is engaging and visual, but truthfulness slips when you examine the actual parameters closely. The 'exposure' frame works because iterative refinement does resemble accumulated light, but diffusion sampling is fundamentally different from photography.

Excellent mapping with no user-facing controls. VAE decode is a black-box transformation (latent → pixel), and chemical development is also a black-box transformation (exposed silver halide → metallic silver). The analogy is remarkably truthful: both are hidden processes that 'reveal' an image. Strength: intuitive, requires no parameter explanation, visually evocative. Weakness: users cannot control VAE behavior in this workflow, so it's informational rather than interactive.

attributeScores.rationale: Users label prints before archiving, and they type a filename prefix. The mapping is direct and transparent. Text input remains fully visible and editable.

mappingScores.rationale: Strong mapping. The print dryer is an intuitive finalization step, and the text input for naming is clear. The metaphor suggests that images are being dried, labeled, and filed — which maps to saving. Minor weakness: the actual output is a digital file, not a physical print, but the metaphor captures the essence of 'finalization and archival'.

ioAnalysis.rationale: Text inputs (positive and negative prompts) remain fully textual and visible throughout — users see exactly what they're typing. No abstraction or obfuscation. Model selection is clearly presented as 'camera body' with named options. Intermediate latent space is abstracted as 'blank film roll' and 'exposure chamber' — reasonably intuitive but not photorealistic. Final output is saved as an image file (pixel data), and the metaphor endpoint (print dryer) suggests a finished photograph — the analogy works well. Weakness: diffusion latent space is not truly visual like film, and the final output is digital, not printed. Score reflects these minor gaps.

scores.rationale: The Darkroom metaphor is cohesive and intuitive, leveraging the strong photographic analogy to make a diffusion workflow feel natural. Strengths: (1) Text prompts remain explicit and visible in light setups (9/10 textInputHandling); model selection is clear (9/10 modelInputHandling); the camera body, lighting, exposure chamber, and developer bath all form a recognizable pipeline that experienced photographers will find familiar. (2) All critical parameters have controls: steps, CFG, seed, sampler, dimensions, batch size, and filename are represented. (3) The scene background provides spatial context and atmosphere. (4) Most mappings score 7-8, with VAE decode and Save Image particularly strong. Weaknesses: (1) CFG scale as 'light intensity' is somewhat forced (6/10 truthfulness on that specific control); sampler algorithms don't map intuitively to photographic tools (5/10 intuitiveness). (2) Intermediate latent space is abstracted as 'film roll' and 'exposure chamber,' which works but isn't visually rigorous — real film is physical, latent space is not (7/10 intermediateHandling). (3) Final output is a digital image file, not a printed photograph, though the metaphor endpoint suggests a finished print (7/10 finalOutputHandling). Fractal consistency is high: all elements share the photography/darkroom vocabulary, and no mappings feel wildly out of place. KSampler is the most complex element (exposure chamber) but still intuitive. Overall, this metaphor successfully makes diffusion sampling feel like a real-world process that most people can grasp, even if the underlying algorithms are not photographically accurate.
